Our Approach

We use Scrum and agile development to translate your business needs to technology features.

  • DE
  • EN

Why use Scrum?

 

A step-by-step overview of Scrum

Scrum is an empirical approach at dealing with unpredictability and solving complex problems. It uses self-organizing events and time boxed periods, to iteratively ship increments of a potentially releasable product, which may be a software feature or a new user interface design. Recurring events such as a Daily Scrum meeting create regularity, keep the Scrum Team up-to-date, and minimize the need for meetings.

Scrum Teams are self-organizing and cross-functional. They consist of a Product Owner, the Development Team, and a Scrum Master, and may involve representatives from the business side, software development, design, as well as testers. A cross-functional Scrum team is created to cover all required competencies for a project and is designed to optimize flexibility, creativity, and productivity.

The goal of Scrum is to deliver a Done Increment. A software release is the sum of a number of Increments that have been Done during previous Sprints.

Product Backlog

 

Step 1

The Product Owner who represents the stakeholders and is the voice of the customer, is responsible for ensuring that the development team delivers value to the business. He starts and maintains the Product Backlog, an ordered list of requirements, that he writes in story format - from the end-user's point of view. The Product Backlog consists of features, bug fixes and other requirements that need to be done to successfully deliver a viable product. During the course of a project, our Product Owner adds and maintains Product Backlog Items (PBIs) based on considerations such as business value, dependencies, risk and completion deadline.

Sprint Planning and Sprint Backlog

 

Step 2

The Sprint Planning meeting takes place at the beginning of each sprint and is a time-boxed event that lasts no more than 8 hours for a one-month Sprint. 

The Sprint Planning meeting answers the following:

  • What can be delivered in the Increment resulting from the upcoming Sprint?
  • How will the work needed to deliver the Increment be achieved?

In the Sprint Planning meeting, the Scrum team sets a Sprint Goal, which is the goal to be achieved by the end of the Sprint, by implementing a number of selected Product Backlog Items. Work is selected from the Product Backlog and moved to the Sprint Backlog. For each Sprint Backlog Item the Scrum team estimates the size of the task and defines a Definition of Done (DOD), which is a mutually agreed condition for signing-off the task as done. The Sprint then starts immediately after the Sprint Planning meeting.

Sprint and Daily Scrum

 

Step 3

As described by the Scrum Guide, a Sprint is a time-box of one month or less (i.e. one or two weeks each) during which a “Done”, useable, and potentially releasable product Increment is created. Each Sprint has a clear list of what is to be built, an estimate of the work to be done and a flexible plan on how to achieve it. During a project, Sprints need to be of the same duration to enable predictability, by ensuring inspection and adaptation of progress toward a Sprint Goal at least every calendar month. Sprints also limit risk to one calendar month of cost.

During the Sprint:

  • No changes are made that would endanger the Sprint Goal;
  • Quality goals do not decrease; and,
  • Scope may be clarified and re-negotiated between the Product Owner and Development Team as more is learned.

Every day, at the same time, the Scrum Team holds a Daily Scrum meeting that is limited to 15 minutes. This meeting has the purpose of aligning everybody on the team on each team member's progress, by having everyone answer three questions: What have I done yesterday? What will I do today? Are there any impediments that prevent me or my team members from achieving the Sprint Goal.

Working Software Increment and Sprint Review

 

Step 4

At the end of the Sprint, the Sprint Review meeting takes place to inspect the software Increment and the Product Backlog. Each member of the Development Team showcases their work to the rest of the Scrum Team and the client to elicit feedback and to foster collaboration. The Scrum Team and the Product Owner then explain what Product Backlog Items have been Done and which ones have not been completed. Based on this and on what has been Done during the Sprint, attendees discuss what can be done during the next Sprint to optimize value. If needed, the Product Owner may project likely completion dates, based on the work Done in previous Sprints of the project.

The Scrum team collaborates on what to do next, revises the Product Backlog and defines the probable Product Backlog Items for the next Sprint.

From a business point of view, valuable to the customer, the Sprint Review verifies:

  • How the marketplace or potential use of the product might have changed and what is the most valuable thing to do next; and,
  • The timeline, budget, potential capabilities, and marketplace for the next anticipated release of the product
